head.supplied: Question 1: Whether a science about the soul can be acquired by us

div.p: So it is asked first whether a science about the soul can be acquired by us.

That about which there is a science is intelligible, since when a science is a state of the intellect, the object of the science ought to be intelligle; but the soul is not intelligible, since all our knowledge comes from the senses, and intellection itself does not take place without phantasms, but the soul is not available to sense perception, nor does it create phantasms; ergo et cetera.

Further, one and the same thing cannot be moving and moved at the same time, since then the same thing would be in act and potentcy in the same respect; but that which is known is moving with respect to that which knows; ergo one and the same thing cannot be knowing and known, but that would be the case if there were a science about the soul.

Further,
just as the eye of the night-raven stands to the light of the sun, so does our intellect stand to those things which are most clear in nature,
Cf. Arist. Metaph. II.1 993b9--11 (νυκτερίς).
to which the soul belongs, at least the human soul; but the eye of the night-raven cannot apprehend the light of the sun; ergo et cetera.
Further, our intellection is continuous and temporal; but the soul, since it is indivisible and perpetual, is neither continuous nor temporal; ergo et cetera.
The opposite holds according to the determination of the Philosopher.

It must be said that since science is a state acquired by demonstration, and three elements are required for a demonstration (that is, a subject, an attribute, and a principle by which the attribute is ascribed to the subject), where these three can be found it can be said that there is a science. But now the soul is some sort of subject which has properties and attributes, as will be apparent below. But there are some principles by whic these attributes can be proved concerning the soul. For if the definition of the soul is accepted as the middle term,
by that the property of the soul can be concluded to belong to the soul
The latin reads per ipsum concludi potest propria passio eius de anima. It is ambiguous to me what the eius qualifies, but it is here interpreted to qualify passio and refer to the soul.
, and in this way something can be known about the soul or there can be some sort of science about the soul.

Further, accidents are not things by themselves but belong to something else. Ergo one who knows the accidents can be led to a knowledge about that which they belong to. But now many accidents that belong to the soul itself are obvious to us: For productive activities are known to use, but they cannot take place without intellection, and intellection procedes from some sort of power, and a power flows from the essence; and it is the same with other activities such as those which procede from the irascible. Thus, by many things which are known to us we may arrive at a knowledge about the soul. But since knowing is knowing through causes, and such knowledge about the soul proceeds by effects, not by causes, the Philosopher therefore, as he presents the knowledge about the soul, calls the knowledge
an account Arist. DA I.1 402a4
. But by extension it can be called a science.

To the first argument it must be said that the minor premise is false. And to the supporting argument it must be said that something is available to sense perception in two ways: either by its possession or by privation. By privation just like shadows and indivisible objects, such as a point and a unity. By possession in two ways: either by its own species or by the species of something else; when by its own species, it is just like when a colour is seen,
when by the species of something else, it is just like when the son of Diares is seen.
Arist. DA II.6 418a20--22
. Hence although the soul is not available to sense perception in itself, it is still available to sense perception by something else, that is by its effects, and in the same way,
although it does not produce phantasms on its own, it produces another phantasm, which may lead to knowledge about it.
The Latin reads: licet per se phantasma non faciat, aliud [aliquid MS] tamen phantasma facit, quod in eius cognitionem ducere potest. We must understand this to mean that the although there cannot be a phantasm of the soul, as it is not perceptible, it produces an external activity that may yield phantasms by which we can acquire knowledge about the soul as origin of those activities. The manuscript reading something is thus replaced by another to emphasise the externality (but not contingency) of the produced activities.

To the next it must be said that movement is said in two ways: in one way it is the act of an imperfect object, just as it is defined by the Philosopher in
the third book of the Physics;
Arist. Phys. III.2 201b31--33
, and in another way it is the act of the perfect being, just as intellection and cognition are said to be movement: In the first way the same thing cannot be moving and moved by itself, but accidentally nothing prevents it, just as the sailor moves the ship by himself, and in that being moved he moves himself. In the other way nothing prevents the same thing from moving itself. But there is although a difference: For there is one sort of substance which always actively knows, and such a substance can know by itself, just as it is the case with the first cause and the intelligences; but there is another sort of substance which does not always actively know, just as the human soul, and such a thing does not know by itself, since it knows nothing except when it is actualized, and such a substance, since it potentially knows, is not actualized except by something else, that is by a intelligible species, and therefore it can know itself through something else. For by the fact that the soul knows and object by a species it can know its own activity, and by the activity it can reflect itself on its own essence; hence our soul in a certain way knows itself just as the sailor moves the ship.

To the next it must be said that although the eye of the night-raven cannot apprehend the light of the sun directly, it can although apprehend some brightness indirectly, and if its sight were discursive, then it could know the light of the sun. But now, although our intellect cannot arrive at a perfect knowledge about the separate substances, some of their effects are still apparent to us by which we may be led to a knowledge about them, and since our intellect is discursive, therefore it can arrive at some sort of knowledge of them through their effects. But we know more about the soul than about the separate substances, since the effects of the soul itself, which are apparent to us, are more suited to its power than the effects of the separate substances, which are apparent to us, are suited to their power.

To the next it must be said that our intellection does not take place without phantasms, continuously and temporally, since it does not take place without phantasms. But it does not require that all intellection is continous and temporal.
